properties.title: To package or not to package

children.value: This training introduces you to key concepts in software packaging. When talkning about software packaging, we really mean two things:
A Python package is a way to organize related code by grouping modules into a structured directory. It consists of a folder with an

file and one or more Python modules, making it easier to manage, reuse, and share functionality—especially in larger projects. Think of packages as toolboxes that store useful tools like functions and classes. They can also include sub-packages for more complex organization. This
provides a high-level introduction to Python packages.

Publishing your code and packaging it properly benefits both you and the wider Python community. It helps grow the ecosystem of third-party tools and improves your code through user feedback. Packages make your code easier to use, maintain, and share—whether with colleagues, the public, or even your future self. Even if you don’t plan to share your code, packaging it saves time by making it easier to reuse and update across projects, avoiding inefficient copy-paste practices and promoting cleaner, more maintainable code.
That being said, packaging might not be necessary or beneficial in certain situations:
: For simple scripts that don’t require complex organization or distribution, packaging can be an overkill. A single .py file might suffice.
: If the code is solely for a specific project (e.g., reproducing a figure in an article), packaging might add unnecessary complexity.
: During the initial stages of development, packaging can slow down the iteration process. It’s often more efficient to experiment with code in a simpler structure.
When platform-specific mechanisms are more suitable
: If you need to distribute shell scripts or other platform-specific files, using mechanisms like .deb or .rpm might be more appropriate than Python packages.
When avoiding dependencies is a priority
: If the goal is to have a self-contained script with minimal external dependencies, packaging might introduce unnecessary overhead.
When the code is tightly coupled to a specific environment
: If the code relies heavily on a particular system configuration or environment, packaging might not be the best way to ensure portability.
When the project is not generalized enough

: If the project is too specific or not valuable for the community to benefit from, it might not be worth the effort to package it for distribution.  As a rule of thumb, workflows for a single paper should not be packaged. However, the functions supporting the workflow may be.

You want to make sure that the repository supports software evolution (such as tracking changes, version control and continuous integration) and supports groups of developers with tools such as issue tracking and project organization. An API (Application Programming Interface) for a software package is the set of functions, classes, and methods that the package exposes for users to interact with its features—essentially, it’s the public interface that lets others use the package without needing to understand its internal code.
How to choose what you API should be
Start with what the user wants to accomplish, not how the code works internally.
Ask: What are the 3–5 core things someone will want to do with this package?
Build an API around tasks, not just functions.
Example: If your package processes climate data, users might want load
Group related functionality under intuitive classes or modules.
Don’t expose every internal function—just the ones that support your use cases cleanly.

Think: “What objects or concepts does my package revolve around?” Those are your API anchors. For instance, if you are working with tabular data, you may want to create an object that revolves around tables and design methods to filter by some criteria, append columns, remove rows… Such a library for Python already exists:
and its table object is the
Design the API to feel “Pythonic” and familiar.
Follow the principle of least surprise: it should behave as users expect.
Don’t make users dive into deep submodules unless absolutely necessary.
Expose the most useful functions at the top level of the package.

Decide Between a Functional vs. Object-Oriented API
Use functions if tasks are independent and stateless.
Use classes if there’s a natural object model (e.g., a
It’s okay to offer both if done cleanly—e.g., load_data() returns a
Prototype the API Before You Build It
Write example usage (pseudocode or in a notebook) as if the package already existed.
This helps clarify what feels natural vs. clunky.
Ask a colleague: Would you enjoy using this interface?
Avoid exposing internals that you might want to change.
Keep your API minimal but extensible.

The more maintained, the better. You don’t want to integrate a package that do not have support for future versions of Python.
Public APIs are promises. Once people depend on them, they are hard to break.

Start your Python package with a simple, minimal setup—including basic pyproject.toml, setup.cfg, and README.md files—and gradually add details as your project evolves. This approach helps avoid common mistakes like missing dependencies and makes the process less overwhelming. Begin documenting and organizing your code early to clarify your goals.
To create a package, structure your project as a directory with an
.py file and modular Python files. You can add sub-packages for deeper organization. Use clear imports and expose key functions in your
.py to make the API intuitive and easy to access.

Unit tests are essential for ensuring that each part of your code behaves as expected, making it easier to catch bugs early, maintain code quality, and safely refactor over time. Using a tool like

simplifies writing and running tests by offering a clean, readable syntax and powerful features like fixtures and parameterized testing. It helps developers confidently validate their code and contributes to more reliable and robust software.
These tests can be run on your local machine or integrated into a software registry such as Github. This is called continous integration (CI).
To learn how to write tests in Python and use CI, have a look at

Code review is a vital part of the software development process that helps improve code quality, catch bugs early, and ensure consistency across a project. By having peers review code before it’s merged, teams can identify issues in logic, design, and style, while also sharing knowledge and reinforcing best practices. It fosters collaboration, improves maintainability, and contributes to building more reliable and readable codebases. Additionally, code review can serve as a valuable learning opportunity for both the author and the reviewer.

Question: What is a Python package?

properties.text: A single Python file with reusable code.

children.value: That describes a module, not a package.

properties.text: A directory with scripts and no special files

children.value: Without __init__.py, it’s not recognized as a package.

properties.text: A folder with an __init__.py file and one or more modules.

children.value: This is the standard structure of a Python package: a folder with __init__.py and one or more modules.

properties.text: A zipped archive of Python files

children.value: While zipped packages exist, it's not how a package is defined structurally.
Question: Why is it beneficial to package your Python code?

properties.text: It guarantees your software will run faster.
It eliminates all bugs.

children.value: Good practice helps, but packaging doesn't guarantee bug-free code.

properties.text: It prevents other people from seeing your code.

children.value: Packaging actually makes code more accessible, not less.

properties.text: It helps with reusability, sharing, and long-term maintenance.

children.value: Packaging supports reuse, distribution, and better organization.
Question: When might packaging not be necessary?

properties.text: When your code is modular.

children.value: Modular code is often a reason to package, not to avoid it.

properties.text: When you’re working on a quick prototype or small script.

children.value: Packaging can be overkill for small or temporary projects.

properties.text: When you’re building for open-source distribution.

children.value: That’s a strong reason to package your code.

properties.text: When your code is general-purpose.

children.value: General-purpose code benefits from packaging and reuse.
Question: What is the main role of a software repository like GitHub?

properties.text: To support code development and collaboration.

children.value: GitHub supports development through version control, issues, CI, and collaboration tools.

properties.text: To install Python packages.

children.value: That’s the role of registries like PyPI or Anaconda.

properties.text: To serve as a backup for files.

children.value: While version control offers some backup-like benefits, that’s not the main purpose.

properties.text: To distribute packages to pip and conda.

children.value: Distribution happens through registries, not repositories.
Question: What distinguishes a software registry like PyPI from a repository like GitHub?

properties.text: Registries are private and repositories are public.

children.value: Both registries and repositories can be either public or private.

properties.text: Registries are for discovery and installation; repositories are for development.

children.value: Registries make software findable and installable; repositories manage the development process.

properties.text: Registries support development, repositories handle publishing.
They serve the exact same function.

children.value: They serve complementary but different purposes.
Question: What is an API in the context of a Python package?

properties.text: The internal logic of the software.

children.value: That’s the implementation, not the API.

properties.text: A user interface for the command line.

children.value: That’s a CLI, not an API.

properties.text: The data files used by the software.

children.value: That’s part of the data, not the API.

properties.text: The set of public functions and classes exposed for use.

children.value: The API defines what users interact with—functions, classes, methods.
Question: Which of the following is a best practice when designing a Python package API?

properties.text: Expose all internal helper functions.

children.value: Only expose functions that support the public interface; internal helpers should be private.

properties.text: Start by identifying user tasks and use cases.

children.value: Good APIs are user-focused and task-driven.

properties.text: Use deeply nested imports for organization.

children.value: Deep nesting makes the API harder to use and understand.

properties.text: Avoid documenting your code to reduce clutter.

children.value: Documentation is essential for usability and maintenance.
Question: What is the role of the

properties.text: It provides installation instructions.

children.value: That’s done via pyproject.toml or setup.cfg, not `__init__.py`.

properties.text: It initializes the Python environment.

children.value: It marks the folder as a Python package—not the environment.

properties.text: It defines the public API and marks directories as packages.

children.value: __init__.py defines the package and can be used to expose the public interface.

properties.text: It logs package usage.

children.value: Logging is not a built-in purpose of `__init__.py`.
Question: Why is unit testing important in packaging software?

properties.text: It helps secure your code.
It guarantees your software will be accepted by PyPI.

children.value: Tests are recommended but not required for PyPI.

properties.text: It makes your package smaller.

children.value: Testing has no effect on package size.

properties.text: It ensures individual components behave as expected.

children.value: Unit testing helps verify each part of your code functions correctly.
Question: What is one benefit of peer code review in software development?

properties.text: It helps catch bugs and improve code quality.

children.value: Code reviews are critical for improving quality and catching issues early.

properties.text: It increases the package file size.

children.value: Reviews have no effect on package size.

properties.text: It reduces version history.

children.value: Version control tracks changes regardless of review.

properties.text: It guarantees your code passes all tests.

children.value: Testing ensures code correctness; reviews ensure quality and structure.
